articles.title: AUGUST 1988
articles.summary: This document outlines a busy schedule of astronomical events and club activities for August and early September 1988, hosted by organizations like SJAA and ARAC. Key highlights include talks by Dr. Chris McKay on the search for life on Mars, multiple astronomical observation field expeditions to state parks, and public outreach events like the annual star party and a Mars Watch. The schedule also covers general meetings, an introductory astronomy class, and a swap meet.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces that the Yosemite Star Party reservations are full, but stand-bys are welcome, and those on the list who cannot attend should notify Jim Van Nuland. It also serves as a final reminder for San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) membership renewals, with August being the cut-off month to ensure continued receipt of publications like Sky & Telescope and The Ephemeris.

articles.title: MARS WATCH - '88
articles.summary: The SJAA is organizing a series of public star parties at Branham Lane park in 1988, to allow the public to view Mars during its near-opposition, when it will be closer to Earth than in many years. These events will also feature prominent views of Saturn and other celestial objects, encouraging the public to participate and share the astronomical experience.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY CLASS FIELD EXPEDITION.
articles.summary: A special astronomy class field expedition is scheduled for Friday evening, September 9th, beginning around 8:30 PM. Led by Jack Zeiders, the program grants students exclusive access to the FPOA 30-inch reflector for the evening.

articles.title: AUGUST SPEAKER
articles.summary: Dr. Chris McKay from NASA will be the featured speaker in August, discussing the search for life on Mars. His talk is particularly relevant given the grand opposition of Mars and the ongoing interest in planetary science regarding life on the 'Angry Red Planet'. Members are invited to learn about the steps involved in this quest.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY AND TELESCOPE MAKING -- RENEWALS
articles.summary: This notice announces an early opportunity for independent subscribers to convert their Astronomy and Telescope Making magazine subscriptions to a club rate for 1989. Subscriptions expiring in 1988 can be extended at a pro-rated price, offering significant savings. Interested members must provide a mailing sticker from a recent issue to Jim Van Nuland by early November.

articles.title: SEPTEMBER 3RO SWAP MEET AND EQUIPMENT NIGHT
articles.summary: This article announces a "Swap Meet and Equipment Night" scheduled for September 3rd. It includes a mid-year swap meet starting at 2 pm, followed by the annual slide and equipment show and tell at 8 pm, where members are encouraged to share their astronomy gear, modifications, and astrophotography work. The organizers hope to increase participation, especially from new members, and suggest a parking lot star party afterward.

articles.title: SJAA ANNUAL PICNIC
articles.summary: The SJAA annual picnic at Grant Ranch County Park saw approximately 30 club members attend, along with a curious wild pig. The event faced significant issues due to a communication breakdown, leading to the primary supplier of necessities failing to show up. The author accepts responsibility for not following up on the board's earlier discussions about who was bringing what.

articles.title: VOLUNTEERS FOR THE MARCH WATCH 88 SEASON
articles.summary: The SJAA is recruiting volunteers for their 'MARCH WATCH *88 SEASON' public star parties scheduled for September and October at Branham Lane Park, asking members to bring telescopes and expertise. Volunteers are also sought to organize outreach events at schools and community centers, with a deadline to contact John Gleason by August 12th for inclusion in the Ephemeris. The article also briefly touches on a past event featuring sunspot observations.

articles.title:
AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES
BY DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: The article provides a detailed overview of Branham Lane Park in San Jose as an ideal urban observing site for public astronomical events. It highlights the park's convenient location, ample space for telescopes and parking, and low horizons despite city light pollution. Logistical details for reserving the park, covering lights, and available amenities (or lack thereof) are also provided.

articles.title: BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: The article details August's celestial events, highlighting an exceptional month for meteor enthusiasts with five showers reaching maximum, including the major Perseids on a New Moon Friday night. It also describes a partial lunar eclipse on August 27th, which will be visible from the local area and predominantly penumbral, with a small portion entering the umbra.

articles.title: CIRCUMSTANCES OF THE LUNAR ECLIPSE
articles.summary: This document outlines the Universal Time (U.T.) schedule for a lunar eclipse, encouraging members to observe it and identify lunar features. Additionally, it announces the close approach of the Apollo-class asteroid 1685 TORO in August, its closest since 1972, playfully referencing its potential (though distant) impact risk.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This 'Comet Comments' column by Don Machholz celebrates its tenth anniversary, providing updates on comets. It discusses the current visibility of Periodic Comet Tempel 2 and details the recent discovery of Comet Shoemaker-Holt-Rodriquez. The article also analyzes historical trends in amateur and professional comet discoveries, concluding that the yearly number of comet finds and perihelion passages is highly variable and unpredictable.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document features a series of classified advertisements from mid-1988, primarily offering used astronomical equipment for sale, including various Celestron telescopes, spotting scopes, eyepieces, and accessories. Additionally, it contains a "wanted" ad for specific telescope components and an employment opportunity for an optical systems engineer with experience in laser diode-based optical systems.

articles.title: SPACE SHUTTLE DISCOVERY IS ON THE LAUNCH PAD
articles.summary: Space Shuttle Discovery has been rolled out to launch pad 39B with a tentative launch date of September 6th. Several crucial milestones, including a flight readiness firing, software simulations, and payload installation, must be completed before launch. However, a significant fuel leakage issue, potentially requiring the shuttle to be rolled back for repairs, could delay the mission by several months.

articles.title: CONGRESSIONAL SUBCOMMITTEES VOTE TO KILL SPACE STATION
articles.summary: Congressional subcommittees have voted to significantly reduce or terminate funding for the space station program. The Senate subcommittee approved $200 million for contract termination, while the House subcommittee allocated $30 million for initial costs and $55 million for termination. Both measures include riders allowing for reversal if the next president indicates an intent to proceed with the program, with final decisions pending votes from full committees and the full House and Senate on the FY 89 NASA appropriation.

articles.title: SOVIETS LAUNCH MISSION TO PHOBOS
articles.summary: The Soviet Union has successfully launched two spacecraft towards Mars. One of the missions is specifically designed to rendezvous with Phobos, one of Mars' moons, with the goal of analyzing material by vaporizing it from the surface.

articles.title: MIR REPAIR UNSUCCESSFUL
articles.summary: Soviet cosmonauts conducted an Extravehicular Activity (EVA) to repair a British/Dutch X-ray telescope located on the Kvant astrophysics module, which is docked to the MIR space station. The repair attempt failed when a wrench broke while trying to remove a bracket clamp. A subsequent repair attempt is planned once a new wrench can be delivered.

articles.title: ARIANE 4 LAUNCHED SUCCESSFULLY
articles.summary: The first European Ariane 4 rocket was successfully launched on June 15th. This mission injected three geosynchronous satellites into transfer orbit.

articles.title: PLUTO'S ATMOSPHERE OBSERVED
articles.summary: An astronomy team from MIT, utilizing the Kuiper Airborne Observatory, has made the first direct observation of Pluto's atmosphere. They achieved this by observing the occultation of a 12th magnitude star as Pluto passed in front of it, a technique previously employed to detect Uranus's rings.

articles.title: BY: SARAH STIFF REPORTER DON GRABSKI
articles.summary: This article introduces an upcoming interview with Denise Hutson, a member of the SIAA and author of a notable letter published in Sky & Telescope magazine. The interviewer describes visiting Denise at her welcoming home in San Jose, noting her vibrant personality and the charming, if busy, atmosphere of her family life. The interview itself, despite typical household interruptions, promises to delve into Denise's experiences.

articles.title: Interview Transcript
articles.summary: Denise, a self-taught amateur astronomer, shares how her interest in the field was subtly shaped by her aeronautical engineer father, despite societal norms discouraging it for girls. She discusses her observing habits, preferred equipment, extensive astronomical library, and the challenges and joys of balancing her passion with family life. Denise also advocates for greater participation and camaraderie among women in amateur astronomy clubs.

articles.title: Document Text
articles.summary: Denise Hutson shares her personal journey and passion for amateur astronomy, emphasizing the value of community interaction and encouraging other women to join the hobby despite its male-dominated perception. She recounts learning experiences, a desire for formal astrophysics education, and her continuous pursuit of knowledge. The document also provides an ephemeris for three asteroids—Ceres, Pallas, and Melpomene—listing their Right Ascension, Declination, diameter, and magnitude for specific dates in August.

articles.title: THE 1988 ANNUAL CONFERENCE
articles.summary: The article announces the 1988 Annual Conference, scheduled to take place on August 27th and 28th. The conference will be held from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Lawrence Hall of Science, University of California, Berkeley.

articles.title: FEATURING:
articles.summary: This document details the 1988 AANC Conference, an astronomy event featuring professional speakers from JPL and UC Berkeley, an awards banquet with David Levy, and presentations by amateur astronomers. The conference also includes astrophotography and art exhibitions, product displays, a swap meet, a star party, and pre/post-conference picnics and star parties, with registration information provided.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details various membership types, including general, general with Sky & Telescope subscription, and junior memberships, along with their respective fees. The form provides instructions for submission, payment information, and contact details for the association's treasurer.
